column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$5$5$"So doing a quick scan through the reviews of Wellbutrin
column3: I didn't see anyone else using it for the same reason as me.

column1: For the last 2 years I've been battling with a pretty serious methamphetamine addiction. Before I had ever began taking meth (R.O.A. vaporizing in a pipe) I had battled with depression of variable severity
column2: for almost as long as I can remember. I was also diagnosed with ADD as a young kid and was prescribed Adderall as a fix
column3: but only took it for a short period of time (maybe 3 weeks if memory serves me right). The first time I ever used methamphetamine I felt as if I was a normal person for the first time ever. It allowed me to think clearly
column4: express myself more easily
column5: gave me the greatly needed boost of energy and metabolism (have always been slightly overweight)
column6: reduced anxiety and boosted mood. But of course what goes up must come down (especially when you get arrested). So because of added scrutiny from probation and the court system
column7: I became desperate to find something that allowed me to A.)Not crave meth (the mental withdrawals are awful
column8: and you WILL be severely depressed for a long time) and B.) Provide some relief from my baseline issues. *Now please note*

column1: There is not clinical recomend treatment for methamphetamine abuse. But the few independent studies I examined listed Wellbutrin as one of the most effective M.A.T.'s.
I am currently taking 40mg xR orally once daily
column2: and by the 2nd day I instantly noticed a difference in my mental well being. Compared to how bad off I was and just completely unwilling to stop using meth
column3: I would call this a miracle. And ironically the only other methamphetamine user I know that also has taken Wellbutrin reported similar success as myself
column4: I would say it's criminal that they're not doing more research into using this or other similar meds to help curb methamphetamine addiction. "

column1: 1$Condition: Other$12/9/2019 3:06:02 AM$Reviewer: Let’s not meet again
column2: Wellbutrin
column3: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$"Wellbutrin (and to be fair
column4: my Drs negligent behavior) almost killed me. I have fairly severe C-PTSD with a lot of disassociation
column5: flashbacks and I am prone to severe bouts of anxiety. I saw my psych when I could tell I was heading towards a depression spiral. I could feel all motivation slipping away
column6: and as a college student with ADHD and finals next week she suggested that I try it. “It’s a super easy drug” she said; “it’ll be fine
column7: what’s the worst that could happen?” I thought.

column1: Literally every side effect it could have caused it did— and I only took it for a week and a bit. I didn’t sleep for days at a time. I saw things I knew weren’t there. I had trouble going to gatherings because I got panicky in crowds (never happened to me before. A friend who isn’t me said it was reminiscent of being stoned). I got super paranoid and anxious
column2: was incredibly confused and couldn’t focus
column3: and I felt like I was going to drop dead from a heart attack. Multiple friends stopped me to ask what I was on and if I needed help getting back to my dorm room because you couldn’t see the color of my eyes. But by far the worst part was that it made me incredibly
column4: indescribably suicidal. I have been suicidal most of my life and had attempted before then but Wellbutrin made it 10000% more horror movie-esque. Instead of thinking about normal (??!?) suicidal thoughts I was so out of it that I was seriously thinking/fantasizing  about super graphic imagery.

column2: during the Welbutrin hell week I still managed to get all As in all my finals.

column1: Additionally an immediate family member tried Wellbutrin with eerily similar results.
****btw I want to make it clear that Wellbutrin works for many people
column2: I think this horrible experience is more on the Dr than anything else. My next psychiatrist said it was “borderline malpractice” to put anyone on a new medication that wasn’t 100p necessary before a stressful time much less someone with my background.***"

5$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$3/27/2019 2:49:52 PM$Reviewer: RedLipstick, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$4$5$I was switched to Wellbutrin after taking Zoloft for 6 months. Zoloft helped my depression but I had terrible nightmares that worsened and turned into night terrors/paralysis couldn't take it anymore. I've been on Wellbutrin XR 150mg for 4 days and already seeing an elevated mood, energy increase, overall feeling like my non depressed active self again and it feels amazing! The downside is that every day so far, 2 hours after taking it, I puke a few times and am nauseous almost all morning. I'm not a breakfast person so the first 2 days I took it on empty stomach, thought that might cause sickness but yesterday and today I ate toast with my dose - didn't make a difference. Today I also noticed a metallic taste in my mouth not sure if that's a side effect though. I'm 5 feet and weigh 117 lbs so I'm not sure if the dose is too much taking all at once, my Dr said it should be a good starting dose so idk. I'll give it a few more days before requesting dose change, definitely not giving up on it bc it's working!

column2: I was prescribed quetiapine (that's a whole other message board) and bupropion.

column1: I was on Activas bupropion 150 XL for about six weeks. It stabilized me
column2: but I was still depressed - but functioning. Side effects - waking up early
column3: feeling like a zombie
column4: loss of appetite - went away within that time period.

column1: I've now been on Par Pharmaceutical's bupropion 300 XL for about a month. Side effects are irritability and jitters
column2: but I'm hoping those go away. I tried Activas 300 XL - oval pills - and it seemed to dump a large portion of the medication about two hours after taking it
column3: giving me a zombie effect. It also gave me a headache. Those things may have gone away with time
column4: but I switched back to Par.

column1: Overall I'm content and my depression is completely gone."

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$"Firstly note this medicine not for everyone. Everyone's brain chemestry is different. It is one of the most popular and commonly used antidepressant due to it's general efficiency and fewer shitty side effects than other drugs. Personally
column3: two weeks after starting 150mg bupropion
column4: I'm already starting to feel somewhat better overall.

column1: The way I've understood this drug works is by preventing the recapture of dopamine and noradrenaline. This leads to a slow but steady build up of those two chemicals in the brain. That' why the full efficiency of this drug is obtained a few weeks later after starting taking it. Dopamine is the feel good reward chemical which makes you feel slightly happier in general and makes you want to do things more since you're reward signal in the brain is ""boosted"". Not absolutely sur about the noradrenaline part but I think it's from this chemical adrenaline comes from. This could explain why this drug makes you more awake and energized than normally. Not sure but dopamine too i think helps keep awake. Anyways
column2: even the specialists aren't exactly sure HOW antidepressants exactly works.

column1: So far for me the first few days I felt a little ""something"" positively different about how I felt in general. I've been sadly having trouble to feel emotions and happyness for a very long time. Feel like a machine that mainly works eats and sleep. Now I'm starting to have more energy
column2: want to do more things and actually enjoy myself sometimes. Better mood. I actually smile because I feel like it sometimes instead of smiling because I'M supposed to. Don't oversleep anymore. More sociable. Better attention and focus. Think better. Got some libido back. Losing fat and gaining muscle since im more active. Seems I'm actually starting to enjoy life a little. So far the pros are better than cons. Insomnia (i need seroquel to sleep well)
column3: rise in anxiety are the two downsides. A bit worst in the begining but it lessens. Got used to it. Definately worth it for me."

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$I had struggled with depression on my own before finally giving in and seeing a therapist. I resisted therapy and drugs for years- men are supposed to take care of their own problems....aren't they? Well a series of very trying and anxiety ridden events pushed me over the edge and on my way to getting help- I'm glad I reached out. After going over the options my doctor prescribed Wellbutrin extended release in a 150mg once daily dose (in the morning- don't take it in the evening or you will struggle to fall sleep). I have to say that this drug has really helped me. The very low
column3: sad moods are gone
column4: the fits of anger have subsided
column5: I have more patience at work and with family
column6: I haven't had a drink in months and I no longer think about suicide. I have a much easier time controlling my appetite
column7: which with giving up alcohol
column8: has resulted in a loss of about 20 lbs. My wife has remarked many times that I am 'nicer' now that I am on medication. I have to take her word for it. Seems I was stuck in a dark pit of my own making and couldn't figure a way to get out. I was going through the motions and was thoroughly miserable while doing it
column9: and making everyone around me uneasy. This drug isn't a cure all for bad attitudes and badly lived lives but it can help
column10: possibly
column11: if a person is motivated to change. It will wind you up a bit- I do take a mild sedative at night to sleep. I have also found Wellbutrin to reduce libido but only slightly - this seems to run counter to many others experience. I have addressed that little problem by taking very small doses (7mg- 1/4 of a 25mg pill) of Viagra when the time is right. Otherwise there seem to be few negative side effects
column12: at least for me. I don't like to take drugs but I recognize that Wellbutrin is very useful. Its off patent and I ask for the generic (Bupropion- inexpensive). At some point I hope to taper down and get off it but I could stay on it for a long time if I needed to and could live my life fully.

column3: smoking
column4: gambling

The best thing about the medicine is that I have lost 20 pounds with exercise. The worse thing is that I have developed an addiction to sweets I didn't have before. All in all I am a better person when taking the drug even though a couple of times I have experienced a day of two of sadness but nowhere near like before. column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$4$I was diagnosed with anxiety and depression when I was 14. I tried various medications with little success and many negative side-effects (weight-gain
column3: fatigue
column4: loss of interest/listlessness
column5: etc). For several years i tried to handle my symptoms on my own
column6: and I tauhgt myself how to handle my anxiety attacks but the depression and general anxiety weren't improving. Shortly before I turned 18 I began cognitive behavioral therapy once a week
column7: and a drug regimine to control my symptoms. She prescribed a few different medications along the way to try to find one that worked for me
column8: and one of the trials was Wellbutrin. My mother had taken it with good results
column9: so I consented. After about 3 days I was forced to stop taking the pills - my depression and anxiety had gone from distracting but not over-whelming to literally life-threatening in 72 hours. I began self-mutilating (a habit I had managed to break myself of during my pill-less years) and became incredibly paranoid
column10: agitated
column11: angry
column12: depressed
column13: and I isolated myself from everyone and everything. Again
column14: all within 72 hours! I am not saying this medication is horrible and should never be used by anyone
column15: I just want to share my story so everyone knows that yes it can work (like for my mother)
column16: but it might not and might actually be dangerous (like it was for me). So always be sure to discuss any concerns you have with your doctor
column17: beginning or continuing a medication is a big decision and it could have serious effects on your health and your life both positive or negative. Be careful

column1: 398$Condition: Stop Smoking$1/11/2010 4:40:58 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$1$2$I was taking bupropion to help me quit smoking. I have also been diagnosed with ADHD and Bipolar Disorder so I thought that this might be something to try. well after takeing it for about a week I had a severe allergic reaction. I personally caution all of you that are considering taking this drug for something like quitting smokeing please talk with your doctor about some of the severe side affects to this drug. For me it went well for the first week until i started feeling anxious and a feeling of impending doom. Next came the chest pain and pounding heart. The next day I awoke to find my hands and feet swollen to the point i couldn't wear my gloves or boots. I also had a rash over my entire body and hives. I have stopped taking the medication but 5 days later I am still having trouble breathing a rash and hives. I have been forced to take large doses of several drugs in order to try to combat this reaction to include Epenephrine Benedryl and Prednisone. To let you all know i was the guy that never worried about side affects. I work in the medical field and i was able to monitor my condition and take the right steps in order to treat my condition. If you have any of these side affects don't do like i did go to the ER IMMEDIATELY these are symptoms of what can be a deadly allergic reaction. but pleas don't blow off you doctor when he tells you about side affects listen to them. I will say this though I quit smoking and it works well for that and i felt great most of the time i was on it.

567$Condition: Depression$2/10/2009 5:55:19 PM$Reviewer: me27513, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$Why do docs use only one drug at a time? After 20 years of experimenting with SSRIs, I have an almost ideal combo of Wellbutrin XL (generic) 150 mg each morning PLUS Lexapro 10 mg each night. Wellbutrin made me hyper at first, so I lowered the dosage. It has no negative sexual side effects, so it balances Lexapro nicely (in fact, it has the opposite effect). No weight gain, late-night munchies, sleeping all the time. It's truly different from all the rest. Effexor was awful, Paxil made me fat, Zoloft made me sleepy, Prozac made me nuts, and none of those helped my depression. Wellbutrin saved me, and its generics are so much cheaper than the alternatives. If you're not doing well with the standard Rx, try this...it's truly different, and ask your doc about combining meds.

The side effects i've had is dry mouth, sore throat, and a weird taste in the morning and late at night.  I have also had insomnia but i suffered from that long before and my doctor has prescribed me a sleeping pill that works hand in hand with wellbutrin.  I have noticed that i have been feeling a little more jittery today since i have increased it but i will moniter and see if my amount is too much.  I believe that this will go away after a while though.  lastly i just wanted to add that i ate my feeling when i was depressed and while i am not horribly overweight i am a little and that was one of my biggest reasons for being depressed.  and slowly i am noticing my appitite and cravings going down and i think i am losing a little weight.  thank god!  but i recommend doing your homework and not settling but finding the right drug for you. before i took lexapro and it killed my sex life and i took cymbalta and it made me very dizzy and nauscious.  so i have finally found something that works FOR ME.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$4$4$After dealing with depression for probably two years I finally worked up the nerve to talk to my Dr. about it.  I really didn't want to think I had something I couldn't take care of myself.  I started taking a low dosage of Wellbutrin (actually the generic) once a day about 2 months ago and it has worked very well for me.  The first couple of weeks I felt a little dazed and loopy and I have mild headaches every now and then but those seem to be the only side effects.  I actually lost a little weight when I started but now have come to a stand still in the weight area.  My overall mood has benefited greatly and I find myself enjoying life more and I take things in stride much better. My Dr. has suggested that I only stay on it for a few more months and then go off it which I think I will try as I hate being on a medication every day.  I do think I'll wait until Spring as I live in Upstate New York and our winters always depress me!  I found this sight because I'm looking for a cold medicine with a decongestant that I can take with Wellbutrin.  I don't like having to worry about drug interactions when I just want to take a simple cold tablet.  I would recommend this medicine to anybody that is looking for some releif from depression.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I've been taking Wellbutrin consistently for approximately 8 years now. It was the one and only anti-depressant I was even willing to try based on the possible side-effects. Thankfully
column3: it worked for me because I know many people have to try several different types of meds before they find the right one (or combination) that will work for them. I do recall that it took about six weeks for many of the initial side effects to go away; tingling sensation
column4: bad taste in mouth
column5: mild nausea
column6: insomnia
column7: etc. At the time
column8: I was severely depressed/suicidal and suffered from PTSD as well. The initial bothersome side effects were minor compared to my critical emotional state
column9: so I didn't focus on them too much. I'm glad for that now
column10: because I could've easily decided that the drug wasn't working and found myself getting on the medication roller coaster that many people suffer through. I wouldn't be here if I hadn't taken this drug. The other thing that helped is that I didn't rely on medication alone. At my worst
column11: I was seeing a counselor 2-3 times per week. Eventually
column12: I was able to go on a very light dose (100mg 1xday)
column13: just as a preventative measure. That was 6 years ago. No recurrence of depression and I couldn't identify any side effects that are problematic if I tried. Severe
column14: chronic depression runs in my familly and my first onset of this level of clinical depression was when I was just 9 years old
column15: (I'm 45 now). One of my brothers was even younger. The only family members that are not struggling with severe depression are the ones that are on Wellbutrin. One family member changed meds (from Well to many others) because he couldn't deal with the insomnia and he spent the next 4 years spiraling down to the pits of hell. He went back on it 6 months ago and he's doing well. Yeah
column16: I'm a big fan of Wellbutrin and a fortunate one at that. Good luck to those of you just embarking on recovery. My heart really goes out to you.

I started this drug a month ago for anxiety and anger issues rolled into a little depression. The first week was heaven! I had more energy than I've had in a long time. As a matter of fact, I couldn't stop talking and was talking really fast as if my brain couldn't keep up with my mouth. I mean it was to the point where my mother thought I had been drinking because I am not usually much of a talker. Then the side effects got worse. I couldn't sleep and went 4 nights straight without sleeping. Benadryl, Tylenol PMC and Sominex didn't help. Finally called my MD and got a prescription for some Lunesta to help me sleep. On top of that, my hands shake like crazy and people are always asking me if I'm nervous, had dry mouth, headaches, slight nausea and the WORST of it is the acne. My face, chest, neck and back are broken out worse than it ever was when I was a teen (I'm 31.) I'm going to continue taking it but me and my doc are going to have a serious talk at my next appointment. If anyone else has had problems with the acne and talking nonstop, please email me at [email protected] and let me know if it gets better or worse.
650$Condition: Depression$8/8/2008 7:59:34 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $2$1$2$After being on Zoloft for about 4 years, I found it was no longer working. Starte at just one dose (150mg) in the morning with no bad physical symptoms, although emotionally I was going through hell. Ever since bumping up to the second dose of 150mg, I have constant shortness of breath. Mood is a little better, but not enough to justify this shortness of breath. Also constantly yawning, sleeping poorly (waking up too many times, extremely vivid dreams, waking up too early). Going to talk to my doctor about it. I've read that this drug works better with people who only have depression. Never knew I was overly anxious before Wellbutrin, but beginning to think it is causing me to be so.

I was DESPERATE to keep my marriage intact and to be a better mother. I walked around sad all the time with no desire or motivation for no reason at all. I also seemed angry all the time.
I was a little nauseus and a tiny bit dizzy
column3: but the thing that I noticed most was that I was restless at night and my mind RACED and I could NOT shut it down! I didn't sleep much the 1st few nights so the pharamcist reduced my dosage to 150mg per day instead of 300mg (SR
column4: not XL) and I could sleep again
column5: felt less dizzy and less nauseus as the days went by until eventually I felt normal except for the dry mouth that I have 24/7.

column1: Recently I noticed after 2 months that it seemed to wane just a little and I felt some anxiety again. I asked the pharmacist about increasing my dosage. He put me on 200 mg per day about 3 days ago and WHAM! The nuaseusness hit full force today and I threw up and felt so dizzy that the room continued to spin and I could not function. I have been drinking a lot of water to flush it out of my system and I feel better now. He is now going to let me try 200mg per day in 2 doses 12 hours apart instead of just one big 200 mg dose all at one time.(I weigh less than 120 lbs so it was a bit much for me) Be patient
column2: if you are taking it for less than a month
column3: stay with it for a little longer
column4: the side effects went away for me.

column1: My family members do not know that I am trying this. I noticed that I am much more relaxed and less obsessive about stupid little things and I think more clearly
column2: have more energy
column3: and am a bit more patient with my kids. It helped me to realize how today is important and to enjoy what I have now because  life is too short! I still feel anxious at times
column4: but not like I used to be! Also
column5: I am not so negative all the time and critical about others.

column1: I hope that it continues to work for me!
I wrote a lot in hopes of helping others.

column1: 734$Condition: Depression$12/9/2007 8:20:06 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$4$I have struggled with depression my whole life and I am not 34. I have been one-and-off meds since 2000. In April 2007 I went back on the meds again. This time it was Zoloft
column2: which made me feel terrific when it kicked in
column3: but I gradually needed more and more until I (at 110 lbs) was at the maximum dosage of 200mg generic Zoloft (sertraline) by September 2007. So my psychiatrist added Wellbutrin
column4: which seemed to help. Honestly
column5: as someone who actually works as a license adolescent therapist and has a lot of experience with my own and treating depression.... the cycle never ends. You spend your whole life switching meds
column6: gradually going off the meds
column7: changing meds
column8: and starting meds over. The best thing you can do is read a lot of books about depression and figure out what contributes to your depression. For me
column9: I grew up with an alcoholic parents and basically walked on egg shells. You never knew if you'd be yanked out of bed by your hair in the middle of the night to wash dishes
column10: you could never have a friend over and no matter what you did it was wrong. Research shows this actually interferes with your brain development and contributes to depression. Today
column11: I have a busy career and I have to monitor how much I take on or I get angry and obsessive along with the depression. I can also say you need to marry someone who understands depression and is NOT depressed themselves. The spouse needs to be supportive and you need to have rules. One of our rules is that my husband will never walk away from me (because it sends me into a depressive rage). My husband also realizes that sometimes I say mean and nasty things to him that I would never say if I weren't having a depressive angry moment. It's hard. We have a toddler and my husband is an at home dad. We love our daughter and want her to have a parents at home
column12: but it can't be me with my depression. My husband being at home help lessen my depression because it's less home-management for me. [email protected]

Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$5$This medication was an absolute nightmare for after the first month I was having suicidal thoughts
column3: severe agitation
column4: horrifying nightmares of being stabbed by knives
column5: it was so awfull that I hardly slept at night and I could hardly concentrate and nothing seemed to work when I tried to focus on other things to block the horrifying nightmares and images that plagued my mind even in daytime hours. I complained to my physchiatrist about my symptoms seeming much worse on this med but she'd just smile and tell me to challenge these things and it was not the wellbutrin. I complained for 2 months. then one day I flipped out at work and began screaming like a lunatic at a co worker and then I pushed her. Needless to say 3 weeks later I was Fired! My glorious career and hard earned respect as a top assistant manager went down in a huge firey blaze. the night I was fired from work
column6: I was considering suicide fortunately I called a friend for help. when I went to the Dr. the next day and told her what happened she refused to take me off the medication. so my mother and I told her off and I refused to take the stuff anymore. I was much better a week after I went off the med. I'd like to sue the makers of wellbutrin!!! Any side effects MAKE YOUR DOCTOR LISTEN!!!!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$Wellbutrin gave me my life back. I had been seeing a therapist for months before I told my real doctor about my depression and he gave me a prescription. I just found myself more confused by therapy
column3: but Wellbutrin allowed me to think clear again. I never needed therapy again. Just make sure you withdraw from it slowly. Itried to just stop and it was hard. When I slowly reduced the dose I was able to get off it okay. My sister took Paxil and stayed hooked on it. It also killed her sex drive and caused her divorce. Her husband cheated on her. I didn't have any problems like that with Wellbutrin and I lost 18 pounds! God bless the people who invented this stuff.
